oai_dc:dc.dc:title: J.B. Wilson, funeral undertaker, continues business

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Off-center broadside print advertises the Fayetteville undertaking business of J. B. Wilson. Gives location, undertaking services, and promotes warranted furniture-making as well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides
Broadsides; Undertakers and undertaking; Coffins; Hearses; Death; Death, dying, and bereavament; Furniture
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fayetteville Observer Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: J.B. Wilson was born in Fayetteville in 1834. He learned the trade of cabinet-making as he worked in his father's shop from around 1850 until 1854. He then entered into a partnership with his father and brother as undertakers and furniture makers. Wilson enlisted in the 43rd Regiment C. S. A. when the war broke out. He picked up his trade after the war, and remained Fayetteville's leading furniture dealer and undertaker for decades.
